text: CLOSE ON A FACE.  A nine year old boy, YOUNG COLE, his ey with wonder. watching something intently.  We HEAR the so the P.A. SYSTEM droning Flight Information mingled with t sounds of urgent SHOUTS, running FEET, EXCLAMATIONS. YOUNG COLE'S POV:  twenty yards away, a BLONDE MAN is spr the floor, blood oozing from his gaudy Hawaiian shirt. A BRUNETTE in a tight dress, her face obscured from YOUNG view, rushes to the injured man, kneels beside him, minis to his wound. ANGLE ON YOUNG COLE, flanked by his PARENTS, their faces view, as they steer him away. FATHER'S VOICE (o.s.)

Come on, Son --this is no place for us. YOUNG COLE resists momentarily, mesmerized by the drama. YOUNG COLE'S POV:  intermittently visible through a confu FIGURES rushing through the foreground, the BLONDE MAN re up and touching the cheek of the kneeling BRUNETTE in a g of enormous tenderness, a gesture of farewell, while the SYSTEM continues its monotonous monotone...
Flight 784 for San Francisco is now ready for boarding at inmate number 66578, Greely.

--number 5429, Garcia -- number 87645, Cole... COLE, late thirties, dark hair, comes awake in a bunk cag of many stacked four high along both sides of a long dim corridor.  He blinks in the near dark, shaken, disoriente Then, as he "recovers" from his very vivid dream, WE GET

head_text.subj: FIRST LOOK AT HIS ENVIRONMENT...A WINDOWLESS UNDERGROUND
ETERNAL NIGHT SOMETIME IN THE FUTURE...AN ALMOST COLORLES
"REALITY" OF BLURRED EDGES AND ECHOEY SOUNDS, MUCH MORE

text: Flashlights glare. In the half-light, COLE sees spooky fi GUARDS, moving among the locked bunk/cages. COLE turns and whispers to the occupant of the next cage,
Ssssst!  Jose, what's going on? JOSE's face is almost lost in shadow.  What there is of i youthful.  He's just a scared Puerto Rican kid!
"Volunteers" again. JOSE immediately rolls over and feigns sleep as SCARFACE, menacing guard with a jagged scar running down his cheek, close to COLE's cage and unlocks it.
"Volunteer duty". The PRISONERS in the other cages watch silently with narr
I didn't volunteer.
You causing trouble again?
(controls his temper)
No trouble.
COLE's alone, struggling to get into what looks like a sp in a room where suits hang like ghosts with blank eyes. TITLES BEGIN SUPERED OVER THE SCENE
COLE has the torso of the suit on now and is trying to cl OFFSCREEN VOICE (o.s.)
All openings must be closed. COLE looks for the source of the voice, a tiny grate in t OFFSCREEN VOICE (o.s.)
If the integrity of the suit is compromised in any way, if the fabric is torn or a zipper not closed, readmittance will be denied.

COLE, wearing the "space suit" and a helmet with a plasti steps into a tiny chamber, a kind of air lock.  The heavy clangs shut behind him.  He's alone.  COLE'S breath comes now as he sucks oxygen from the air tanks on his back. On the opposite wall is another door with a huge wheel lo COLE turns the heavy wheel, opens the door, steps through
COLE'S in an ascending elevator that groans and creaks. down at a crudely drawn map he holds in his gloved hand. The map shows a series of tunnels and ladders.

COLE pans a flashlight, probing the filthy sewer he's wad RATS flee the blade of light, scurry across islands of ru The flashlight beam settles on a ladder mounted in the wa Reaching the rusted ladder, COLE starts to climb awkwardl

A SCRAPING NOISE as a heavy man-hole cover is pushed up a aside.  COLE'S helmeted head emerges from below. COLE'S POV THROUGH HIS PLASTIC-VISORED HELMET:  a city in moonlight!  A surreal image of abandoned buildings.  No p anywhere.  The only sounds are the WIND and COLE'S BREATH

COLE'S light reveals abandoned vine-covered automobiles. Moving to the nearest car, COLE searches in the vines for something.  Finds it.  An insect. COLE takes the bug in his gloved hand.  As he clumsily in into a collection tube, something makes him turn. There's something across the street in the dark.  Somethi COLE points his flashlight and reveals...a BEAR!  Startle light, the animal blinks, then stands on its rear legs an ANGLE ON COLE, staring wide-eyed. Then, the BEAR sinks down onto all fours and, trying to a flashlight, it pads quickly down the street.

Using the flashlight to see, COLE reaches down to the cra floor and gets another specimen.  DOGSHIT! The only sound is COLE'S labored BREATHING. Then, a different SOUND.  GRRRR!  A dog.  More GRRRRS.  M dogs.  Then, a YIP.  Then, VICIOUS GROWLS.  It's a DOGFIG

A giant OWL, perched on an overhead traffic light, raises and lifts off...rising higher and higher into the brighte Below, on the street, COLE trudges along, passing deserte buildings, windows broken, rusted signs dangling.

COLE'S light reveals a spider web just inside the store. SPIDER tries to hide from the light. COLE reaches carefully into the web and plucks the spider puts it into one of his specimen tubes. Then, he shines his light all around the once elegant sto nothing but aisle after aisle of moldering consumer goods

As COLE comes out of the store, the first rays of the sun building.  COLE stops, squints into the light through his COLE'S POV:  spray-painted on the wall a long time ago is logo of twelve monkeys holding hands in a circle.  Over i written, "WE DID IT!" COLE looks up. COLE'S POV:  high up on a building across the street, a L patrols a ledge, pauses, looks out majestically over his TTTLES END
ROARING WATER, powerful torrents gushing from nozzles in wall, pummel the still-suited COLE.

Stark naked and shivering, COLE is being scrubbed with br long poles (like the ones used to wash cars) wielded by t FIGURES in bulky decontamination suits, their personas lo windowed masks.  It's a grim scene in a grim cement room dripping walls.  From an unseen source comes an AMPLIFIED AMPLIFIED VOICE (o.s.)
Raise your arms above your head. COLE lifts his arms and the FIGURES start scrubbing his a

Still naked, COLE is seated on a stool while a MASKED TEC in a less elaborate, less bulky decontamination outfit dr blood from COLE'S arm with an old-fashioned hypodermic ne COLE glances toward a single, nearly opaque "window" of t plastic in the rusty iron wall.  VAGUE FIGURES seem to lu behind the translucent aperture, studying him. The TECHNICIAN slips the blood sample through a slot in t

Ushered in by two guards, TINY and SCARFACE, COLE looks a COLE'S POV:  wails hidden by old headlines, articles, map a blackboard covered with elaborate, sophisticated formul heaped with cracked monitors, gerry-rigged computers held string, lasers lost in tangles of cable, ancient tube amp dilapidated cardboard reconstruction of a city, stacks of books and tattered computer printouts...and, seated at a table, staring at COLE, six SCIENTISTS:  an ASTROPHYSICIS BOTANIST, MICROBIOLOGIST, ZOOLOGIST, and a GEOLOGIST.  Th a "modern" science where brilliant new ideas interface wi outdated, patched-together technologies.
James Cole.  Cleared from quarantine.
Thank you.  You two wait outside.
He's got a history, Doctor.  Violence. COLE'S eyes return to the walls. Headlines:  "CLOCK TICKING!  NO CURE YET!"
Anti-social six -- doing 25 to life.
I don't think he's going to hurt us.  You're not going to hurt us, are you Mr. Cole? COLE'S head turns quickly to the ENGINEER.
No, sir. The GUARDS exchange a look, shrug, exit, closing the door
Why don't you sit down, Mr. Cole. COLE goes to the empty chair at the conference table, sit
We want you to tell us about last night.
I went to the surface and I collected specimens like I was told. The SCIENTISTS don't say anything.  They just study him c
(worried)
I mashed the spider, didn't I?
We'll get to the spider later, Mr. Cole.  Right now, we want to know everything that you saw.
COLE, starting to look very tired now, stands at the blac sketching a detailed map of exactly where he was last nig
Where you collected sample #4, what street was that?
Uh...
It's important to observe everything.

I think it was...I'm sure it was 2nd Street. As the SCIENTISTS start to whisper animatedly among thems COLE'S eyes drift across the newspaper clippings taped to wall.  One headline screams, "VIRUS MUTATING!"  Another f a photo of an OLD MAN (DR. MASON, who we'll see again lat and the words, SCIENTIST SAYS, "IT'S TOO LATE FOR CURE". ASTROPHYSICIST'S VOICE (o.s.)
Close your eyes, Cole. Startled, COLE closes his eyes obediently. BLACKNESS.  Like COLE, WE SEE NOTHING.  But we HEAR their ENGINEER'S VOICE (o.s.)
Tell us in detail what you've seen in this room. COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)
Uh, in this room?  Uh... MICROBIOLOGIST'S VOICE (o.s.)
How many of us are there? COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)
Six...seven, if you count me. ASTROPHYSICIST'S VOICE (o.s.)
Tell us about the pictures on the wall... COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)
Uh, you mean the newspapers? A MONTAGE OF OVERLAPPING VOICES (o.s.)

Tell us about the newspapers.  Can you hear my voice?  What do I look like? What does he look like, the man who just spoke?  How old were you when you left the surface? The VOICES blur into a cacophony and FADE INTO the dronin SYSTEM at the airport.

THE DREAM AGAIN!  But at an earlier moment.  YOUNG COLE, by his PARENTS, whose faces are out of view, is watching land through one of the big glass windows that lines the leading to the departure gates. P.A. SYSTEM (o.s.)

Flight 784 now boarding at gate... Suddenly, a SHOUT, followed by raised VOICES, interrupts monotonous airport routine.  As YOUNG COLE and his PARENT to see what's going on, a man we'll call MR. PONYTAIL, hi averted, hurries past them, bumping YOUNG COLE with a Chi Hulls Sports Duffle Bag.

YOUNG COLE sees little more than the gaudy pants, the duf the man's ponytail flopping as he rushes towards the gate Just then, a WOMAN'S VOICE cries out, "NOOOOOOOOO!" YOUNG COLE turns back toward the Security Check Point jus TRAVELERS scatter madly, some diving to the floor, others running.  A TERRIFIED TRAVELER, hitting the floor close b up at YOUNG COLE with panicky eyes, and asks....
Just exactly why did you volunteer?
COLE comes abruptly awake.  Seated now, he's facing the S
Wake up, Cole.
Uh, I didn't hear the...
(tapping a pencil on the table)
I asked you, why did you volunteer?
Well, the guard woke me up.  He told me I volunteered. The SCIENTISTS react, whispering urgently among themselve COLE starts to nod off again, then comes awake with a sta the ENGINEER speaks to him.
We appreciate you volunteering.  You're a very good observer, Cole.
Uh, thank you.
You'll get a reduction in sentence. COLE keeps his face impassive.
To be determined by the proper authorities.
You don't want to jeopardize that reduction, do you, Cole?  Have it taken away?
No, sir!
We have a very advanced program, something very different, requires very skilled people.
An opportunity to reduce your sentence considerably...
And possibly play an important role in returning the human race to the surface of the earth.
We want tough minded people.  Strong mentally.  We've had some...misfortunes with "unstable" types.
For a man in your position...an opportunity.
Not to volunteer could be a real mistake.
(tapping his pencil again)
Definitely a mistake! COLE gives away nothing.  He's in a box here.  He has no He stares at the tapping pencil.
A strikingly "real" world of bright colors.  Extravagant adorn the walls.  A POET, tiny and ruddy faced, squints o glasses as he reads in a booming voice to an AUDIENCE of seated on folding chairs.

Still among the myriad microwaves, the infra-red messages, the gigabytes of ones and zeroes, we find words, infinitesimally small, byte-sized now, tinier even than science lurking in some vague electricity where, if we listen we can hear the solitary voice of that poet telling us, "We are no other than a moving row Of Magic shadow-shapes that come and go Round with the Sun-illumined Lantern hold In Midnight by the Master of the show." As the POET reads, we STUDY the audience, mostly YUPPIE C JUNKIES or BOHEMIANS.  Among them, a light-haired woman o eight, soberly dressed, wearing glasses.  She's KATHRYN R it's her beeper that suddenly BEEPS.  BEEP!  BEEP! POET'S VOICE (o.s.)

"The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, Moves on:  nor all your Piety nor Wit Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line, Nor all your Tears wash out a Word of it." BEEP!  BEEP!  Scowling at the outrageous interruption, th looks up from the text just as RAILLY, tumbling, shuts of beeper and rises, embarrassed.  As she makes her way to a the glaring POET continues...
"Yesterday This Day's Madness did prepare; Tomorrow's Silence, Triumph or Despair: Drink!  for you know not whence you came, nor why: Drink!  for you know not why you go, nor where."
DETECTIVE FRANKI leads RAILLY past crowded holding cells.

-- so they get there and they ask the guy real nice for some kind of i.d., and he gets agitated, starts screaming about viruses. Totally irrational, totally disoriented, doesn't know where he is, what day it is, alla that stuff.  All they got was his name.  They figure he's stoned out of his mind, it's some kinda psychotic episode, so they're gonna bring him...
He's been tested for drugs?

Negative for drugs.  But he took on five cops like he was dusted to the eyeballs.  No drugs.  You believe that? FRANKI pauses, indicating a tiny observation window of th glass in an otherwise solid door, and RAILLY looks throug RAILLY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDOW:  a MAN, his back to her, strait-jacket and prison denims, examining the wall of th cell with the distorted intensity of a "mental case".
You have him in restraints.

Were you listening?  We got two officers in the hospital.  Yeah, he's in restraints, plus the medic gave him enough stellazine to kill a horse.  Look at him!  Still on his feet. RAILLY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDOW:  the MAN in the cell tur right at her.  In spite of the cuts and welts, it's clear
That would explain the bruises, I guess.  The struggle.
You want to go in?  Examine him?
Yes, please.  You said he gave a name...
(unlocking the door)
James Cole.  That's everything we got.  None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants.  Nothing. You want me to go in with you?
(entering)
No, thank you.
I'll be right here...just in case.
COLE stares at RAILLY.  The environment is intensely real colors...each sound, however slight, very distinct, almos and yet she appears to him almost like a vision.
Mr. Cole?  My name is Doctor Railly. I'm a psychiatrist.  I work for the County -- I don't work for the police. My only concern is your well being -- do you understand that?
I need to go now.

I'm going to be completely honest.  I'm not going to lie to you.  I can't make the police let you go...but I do want to help you.  And I want you to trust me.  Can you do that, James?  May I call you "James"?
"James"!  Nobody ever calls me that.
(frowns, studies him)
Have you been a patient at County? Have I seen you someplace?
No, not possible.  Listen, I have to get out of here.  I'm supposed to be getting information.
What kind of information?
It won't help you.  You can't do anything about it.  You can't change anything.
Change what?
I need to go.
Do you know why you're here, James.
Because I'm a good observer.  Because I have a tough mind.
I see.  You don't remember assaulting a police officer...several officers?
They wanted identification.  I don't have any identification.  I wasn't trying to hurt them.
You don't have a driver's license, James?  Or a Social Security card?
No.
Why not?  Most people have some ID.
You wouldn't understand.
You've been in an institution, haven't you, James?  A hospital?
I have to go.
A jail?  Prison?
Underground.
Hiding?
I love this air.  This is wonderful air.
What's wonderful about the air, James?
It's so clean.  No germs.
You're afraid of germs?
I have to go.
Why do you think there aren't any germs in the air, James?
This is April, right?
July.
(sudden panic)
July?!
Do you know what year it is?
What year is it?
What year do you think it is?
You think it's July of 1995?  That's the future, James.  Do you think you're living in the future?
(slightly confused)
No, 1995 is the past.
1995 is the future, James.  This is 1989. COLE looks stunned.
COLE, bound tightly by the strait-jacket, heavy manacles ankles, is being escorted down the corridor by two surly
Where are you taking me?
South of France, buddy.  Fancy hotel. You're gonna love it.
South of France?!  I don't want to go to the South of France.  I want to make a telephone call. POLICEMAN #2 smirks as he unlocks a heavy steel door.
Zip it, scumbag -- you fooled the shrink with your act, but you don't fool us. Then, POLICEMAN #2 swings the steel door open and sunligh overwhelms COLE, blinding him in a dazzling fury of white
A Mini-van, the kind of vehicle used to transport a half prisoners, crawls through a busy street.  The Police Depa logo is prominent on the side of the van beneath barred w

Fierce spray recalls the decontamination in the future. stands stark naked under the shower while two muscular at PALMER and BILLINGS, supervise. As PALMER shuts off the water, BILLINGS hands COLE a towe starts inspecting his scalp...
Lemme see your head, Jimbo, see if you got any creepy crawlies.
I need to make a telephone call.
(pulling Cole's head)
Gotta work that out with a doctor, Jimbo. Can't make no calls 'til the doctor says.
It's very important.

What chew gotta do, Jimbo, is take it easy, relax into things.  We all gonna get along fine if you just relax. COLE gets the hint of menace in the message and submits t lice inspection, only his eyes revealing his frustration.

COLE stands in the doorway, stunned by his first sight of large room.  His eyes go to the heavily-grilled windows w light pours in from outside.  Then, to the TV, where a CA COMMERCIAL makes raucous noises. PATIENTS, in K-Mart street clothes or ratty robes, stare at the TV, or play cards, pace, or just stare blankly. BILLINGS is at COLE'S side, beckoning to a patient, JEFFR a twenty year old white youth dressed in khakis and a pla
Jeffrey.  Yo!  Jeffrey.  This here is James. Whyncha show James around?  Tell him the TV rules, show him the games an' stuff, okay?
(with a sly look)
How much you gonna pay me?  Huh?  I'd be doing your job.
Five thousand dollars, my man.  That enough?  I'll wire it to your account as usual, okay?
Okay, Billings.  Five thousand.  That's enough.  Five thousand dollars.  I'll give him the Deluxe Mental Hospital Tour. As BILLINGS walks away chuckling, JEFFREY turns to COLE.

Kid around, kid around.  It makes them feel good, we're all pals.  We're prisoners, they're the guards, but it's all in good fun, you see? COLE nods and JEFFREY indicates card tables where PATIENT playing cards, checkers, chess, or working on jig saw puz

Here's the games.  Games vegitize you. If you play the games, you're voluntarily taking a tranquilizer. COLE sees a partially completed puzzle of the well-known THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM, depicting a serene world of animal
What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.
I need to make a telephone call.

A telephone call?  That's communication with the outside world!  Doctor's discretion.  Hey, if alla these nuts could just make phone calls, it could spread.  Insanity oozing through telephone cables, oozing into the ears of all those poor sane people, infecting them!  Whackos everywhere!  A plague of madness. (suddenly sly and confidential)

In fact, very few of us here are actually mentally ill.  I'm not saying you're not mentally ill, for all I know you're crazy as a loon.  But that's not why you're here.  Why you're here is because of the system, because of the economy. (indicating the TV)

There's the TV.  It's all right there. Commercials.  We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. But if you don't buy a lot of stuff, you know what?  You're mentally ill! That's a fact!  If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices... (getting hysterical)
A woman orderly, TERRY, turns from the feeble PATIENT she
Take it easy, Jeffrey.  Be calm. Abruptly, JEFFREY stifles his hysteria, takes a deep brea continues, completely calm now.  But COLE isn't listening mesmerized by the TV.

So if you want to watch a particular program, say "All My Children" or something, you go to the Charge Nurse and tell her what day and time the show you want to see is on.  But you have to tell her before the show is scheduled to be on.  There was this one guy who was always requesting shows that had already played.  He couldn't quite grasp the idea that the Charge Nurse couldn't just make it be yesterday for him, turn back time ha ha.  What a fruitcake!! This last thought actually penetrates COLE'S focus on the he turns to JEFFREY who's picking up speed again.

Seriously, more and more people are being defined now as mentally ill.  Why? Because they're not consuming on their own.  But as patients, they becone consumers of mental health care.  And this gives the so-called sane people work! (hysteria again)

head_text.subj: SYSTEM IN HARMONY LIKE A BIG MACHINE...

text: Okay, that's it, Jeffrey, you're gonna get a shot.  I warned you...
(calming himself, smiling)

Right!  Right!  Carried away, heh heh. I got "carried away".  Explaining the workings of...the institution. Just then, TJ WASHINGTON, a somber-looking African Americ bathrobe, taps COLE on the shoulder.
I don't really come from outer space.
This is TJ Washington, Jim -- he doesn't really come from outer space.
Don't mock me, my friend. (to Cole)

It's a condition of "mental divergence". I find myself on another planet, Ogo, part of an intellectual elite, preparing to subjugate barbarian hordes on Pluto. But even though it's a totally convincing reality in every way...I can feel, breathe, hear...nevertheless, Ogo is actually a construct of my psyche.  I am mentally divergent in that I am escaping certain unnamed realities that plague my life here.  When I stop going there, I will be well.  Are you also divergent, friend? The P.A. SYSTEM interrupts, startling COLE. P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.)
James Cole.  Report to Staff.  James Cole!
Staff!  Whoo!  Time for Staff.  Now the geniuses cure you.  Hallelujah!
COLE is agitated, speaking forcefully.

This is a place for crazy people!  I'm not crazy! RAILLY, four other PSYCHIATRIC RESIDENTS, including RAILL friend, MARILOU MARTIN, and their chief, DR. OWEN FLETCHE around a beat-up conference table, watching COLE, who sit the doctors, with BILLINGS looming behind him.  (Some of bear a strong resemblance to the SCIENTISTS OF THE FUTURE
We don't use that term..."crazy", Mr. Cole.
Well, you've got some real nuts in here! Listen to me, all of you -- I have to tell you something that's going to be difficult for you to understand, but...
James...please.  These are all doctors here and we want to help you.
Mr. Cole -- last night you told Dr. Railly you thought it was... (checking a file)
1995. ... How about right now?  Do you know what year it is right now?
1989.  Look, I'm not confused.  There's been a mistake, I've been sent to the wrong place. Suddenly, COLE reaches out and BILLINGS lunges forward, b is just grabbing a pad and pencil.
Hey, I'm not going to hurt anybody. FLETCHER restrains BILLINGS with a hand signal.
(drawing)
Do any of you know anything about the Army of the Twelve Monkeys?  They paint this, stencil it, on buildings, all over the place. COLE waves a sketch of the dancing monkey logo we saw ear
Mr. Cole...

Right.  I guess you wouldn't, this is 1989, they're probably not active yet. That makes sense!  Okay.  Listen to me, three billion people died in 1995. Three billion, got that?  Almost the whole population.  Of the world! Only about one percent survived. DOCTORS exchange knowing looks.  This is an old story, ap
Are you going to save us, Mr. Cole?
Save you?  How can I save you?  It already happened!  I can't save you.  I'm simply trying to get some information for people in the present so that someday... (sees their eyes)

You don't believe me.  You think I'm crazy.  But I'm not crazy.  I'm a convict, sure, I have a quick temper, but I'm as sane as anyone in this room.  I... COLE stops, sees DR. FLETCHER tapping his pencil.  COLE'S that tapping before -- in the future!  It disorients him.
Can you tell us the name of the prison you've come from? COLE doesn't answer.  He's staring at the tapping pencil.
Does this bother you, Mr. Cole?
(recovering, new tack)
No!  Look, I don't belong here!  What I need to do is make a telephone call to straighten everything out.
Who would you call, Mr. Cole, who would straighten everything out?
Scientists.  I'm supposed to report in to them.  They'll want to know they sent me to the wrong time.
So you could talk to these scientists and they do what?  Send you to the future?
No, no.  I can't talk to them.  It's called, "voice mail".  I'm supposed to leave messages. They monitor it from the present.
"From the present."  We're not in the present now, Mr. Cole?
No, no.  This is the past.  This has already happened.  Listen...
Mr. Cole, you belong in 1995 -- that's the present, is that it?
No, 1995 is the past, too.  Look...
These scientists, Mr. Cole?  Are they doctors like ourselves? Two of the residents exchange quick knowing looks.
No!  I mean yes, but... Look, I've been given a lot of drugs but I'm still perfectly lucid. You have to let me use the phone.  One call! COLE looks desperately toward RAILLY, pleading eyes meeti
Four little KIDS SCREAM and SQUABBLE while the phone CHIR insistently in the tiny, cluttered apartment and a harrie lunges for the phone, answers sharply...
Yes? (listens, frowns, then)
Whaaaaat?  "Voice mail"!  I don't know what you're talkin' about. ... Is this a joke?  I don't know any scientists. James who?  Never heard of you! The MOTHER slams down the phone.
A dismayed COLE still has the receiver in his hand.  Symp RAILLY takes it from him.
It wasn't who you expected? COLE is clearly agitated, starts to pace, upset.  Nuts?
It was some lady.  She didn't know anything.
Perhaps it was a wrong number...

No.  That's the reason they chose me -- I remember things. RAILLY frowns, studying the distracted man with intense i It's clear COLE is becoming a special patient and RAILLY' detached demeanor is giving way ever so slightly.
James, where did you grow up?  Was it around here?  Around Baltimore?
(lost in thought)
What?
I have the...strangest feeling I've met you before...a long time ago, perhaps. Were you ever...?

Wait!  This is only 1989!  I'm supposed to be leaving messages in 1995.  It's not the right number yet.  That's the problem.  Damn!  How can I contact them? RAILLY recovers her distance, her poise, as she takes a b pours out some tablets, and holds them out to COLE.
James, take these. (watching him step back)
Please -- I helped you like I said I would.  Now I want you to trust me.
MR. PONYTAIL races past the startled YOUNG COLE.
Was it JEFFREY wearing gaudy pants and a ponytail?  It wa definitely JEFFREY'S VOICE. TRAVELERS dive for cover as a WOMAN'S VOICE cries out...

The TERRIFIED TRAVELER looks up at YOUNG COLE, makes eye doesn't speak.  The TERRIFIED TRAVELER looks a lot like D Just then, YOUNG COLE is distracted by a running figure. the BLONDE MAN in the Hawaiian shirt, but he's not injure sprinting toward the gates, glancing back over his should moustache slightly askew! A sharp CRACK of a GUNSHOT rings out!  Then, DAZZLING LIG Everything goes white!

COLE'S eyes blink awake, blinded by a flashlight. He's lying in one of thirty beds in a darkened ward.  Dis Which world is this?  The room is full of BREATHING, SNOR occasional MOANS.  He can barely discern the shadowy figu an ORDERLY and a NURSE, making their rounds, checking eac His eyes adjusting to the darkness, COLE watches them exi He turns and sees a patch of moonlight coming in a barred With a quick glance at the sleeping PATIENTS, he slips ou bed, makes his way stealthily to the window, peers out. COLE'S POV:  the moon, glowing in the sky, illuminating a tree.  Under the tree, in silhouette, a COUPLE embraces, ANGLE ON COLE, looking out the window, absorbed. VOICE (o.s.)
It won't work. You can't open it. Alarmed, COLE turns, sees JEFFREY in the next bed.
You think you can remove the grill but you can't.  It's welded. COLE checks the grill anyway.

See?  I toldja.  And all the doors are locked, too.  They're protecting the people on the outside from us.  But the people outside are as crazy as us. COLE has become preoccupied with a small SPIDER creeping the window sill.  He's staring at it when he's distracted sudden SOUND.  Grabbing the SPIDER, COLE scrambles back i just as the door opens and an ORDERLY probes the dark roo the blade of his flashlight. ANGLE ON COLE, in bed, feigning sleep. The flashlight clicks off and COLE hears the door close. For a long moment the ward is silent except for BREATHING SNORES, occasional MOANS.  Then, COLE hears JEFFREY'S hoa whisper, picking up right where he left off.
You know what "crazy" is?  "crazy" is "majority rules".  Take germs for example. Although COLE is preoccupied with the SPIDER struggling t out of his fist, he can't help reacting to the word, "ger
Germs?!

In the 18th century there was no such thing!  Nobody'd ever imagined such a thing -- no sane person anyway.  Along comes this doctor...Semmelweiss, I think.  He tries to convince people... other doctors mostly...that there are these teeny tiny invisible "bad things" called germs that get into your body and make you...sick!  He's trying to get doctors to wash their hands.  What is this guy...crazy?  Teeny tiny invisible whaddayou call 'em?..."germs"! As JEFFREY warms to his subject, getting excited, COLE tr figure out where to put the SPIDER. JEFFREY (cont.)

So cut to the 20th century!  Last week in fact, right before I got dragged into this hellhole.  I order a burger in this fast food joint.  The waiter drops it on the floor.  He picks it up, wipes it off, hands it to me...like it was all okay. No alternative.  COLE pops the SPIDER in his mouth and sw it as JEFFREY prattles on...

"What about the germs?"  I say.  He goes, "I don't believe in germs.  Germs are just a plot they made up so they can sell you disinfectants and soap!" Now, he's crazy, right?  Hey, you believe in germs, don't you?
I'm not crazy.
Of course not, I never thought you were. You want to escape, right?  That's very sane.  I can help you.  You want me to, don't you?  Get you out?
If you know how to escape, why don't you...?
Why don't I escape, that's what you were going to ask me, right?  'Cause I'd be crazy to escape!  I'm all taken care of, see?  I've sent out word.
What's that mean?

I've managed to contact certain underlings, evil spirits, secretaries of secretaries, and assorted minions, who will contact my father. When he learns I'm in this kind of place, he'll have them transfer me to one of those classy joints where they treat you...properly.

head_text.subj: FOR THE NUT CASE LUNATIC MANIAC DEVILS...

text: PATIENTS are waking up as the NURSE and two ORDERLIES bur dorm and head straight for JEFFREY who's struggling to ca
Sorry.  Really sorry.  Got a little agitated.  The thought of escaping crossed my mind and suddenly...suddenly I felt LIKE BENDING THE FUCKING BARS

head_text.subj: BACK, RIPPING OFF THE GODDAMN WINDOW

text: COLE watches the ORDERLIES grab JEFFREY and haul him away
You dumb assholes!  I'm a mental patient! I'm supposed to act out.  Wait til you morons find out who I am.  My father's gonna be really upset.  AND WHEN MY

head_text.subj: FATHER GETS UPSET, THE GROUND SHAKES

text: ANGLE ON TV SCREEN/A VIDEO IMAGE OF A LAB MONKEY, convuls pathetically, a victim of shocks from the numerous wires to his tiny, restrained body. ANGLE ON COLE, sitting, writing intensely in a magazine w crayon, surrounded by dull-eyed PATIENTS in pajamas and r robes, staring at the shuddering LAB MONKEY on the TV scr JEFFREY'S VOICE (o.s.)
Torture!  Experiments!  We're all monkeys COLE locks up, startled, as JEFFREY, one eye bruised blac the seat next to him.
They hurt you!
Not as bad as what they're doing to kitty. ANGLE ON TV, showing a laboratory CAT turning in mad circ eating its own tail, while a NEWS REPORTER narrates. TV NEWS REPORTER (v.o.)

These video tapes were obtained by animal rights activists who worked underground as laboratory assistants for several months.  Authorities say there is little they can do until... The video footage now shows LAB WORKERS watching the resu their experiments passively. ANGLE ON COLE, reacting angrily.
Look at those assholes, they're asking for it!  Maybe people deserved to be wiped out!
(startled, turning)
Wiping cut the human race!  That's a great idea!  But it's more of a long term thing -- right now we have to focus on more immediate goals. (sudden whisper)
I didn't say a word about "you know what".
What are you talking about???
You know -- your plan. As COLE stares, befuddled, JEFFREY sees COLE'S magazine.
What're you writing?  You a reporter?
(shielding the magazine)
It's private.
A lawsuit?  You going to sue them? Just then BILLINGS looms over COLE, extending a cup full
Yo, James -- time to take your meds.
ANGLE ON THE TV, a commercial playing:  a beautiful coupl in the surf in slow motion while an eager NARRATOR encour NARRATOR (v.o.)

Take a chance.  Live the moment.  Sunshine. Gorgeous beaches.  The Florida Keys! ANGLE ON COLE, very drugged, seated in front of the TV al other drugged PATIENTS, staring at the screen. ANGLE ON THE TV, showing a picture of the Marx Brothers. TV AWNOUNCER (v.o.)
We'll return to the Marx Brothers in "Monkey Business" following these messages. JEFFREY'S VOICE (o.s.)
Monkey Business!  Monk Key Business. COLE sees JEFFREY sliding into the next chair and smirkin
Get it?  Monk - Key.  Monk! (big grin)
Key! JEFFREY flashes his palm open for one quick moment.  A KE
(groggy)
Wooooo, they really dosed you, bro. Major load!  Listen up -- try and get it together.  Focus!  Focus!  The plan! Remember?  I did my part.
What...???
Not, "what", babe!  When! "When???"
(pressing the key into Cole's hand)
Now! VOICE/TV (o.s.)
Let us guide you to the stocks and bonds that will enhance your portfolio.
(leaping to his feet)
ANGLE ON TV, almost mimicking JEFFREY with an ad...a BULL BEAR and a computer screen showing stock prices fluctuati VOICE/TV (v.o.)
A portfolio tailored to your specific needs and the needs of your loved ones... ANGLE ON COLE, dumbfounded, watching JEFFREY dance crazil

head_text.subj: YES, YES. ENHANCE YOUR PORTFOLIO NOW

text: ANGLE ON BILLINGS, across the ward, reacting to JEFFREY, of the OLD MAN he's helping as another orderly, TERRY, pr beeper, calling for help. ANGLE ON COLE, flabbergasted, as JEFFREY cavorts around t

ANGLE ON A HAND, inserting the last piece into the PEACEA KINGDOM JIGSAW PUZZLE.  Just then, JEFFREY'S HAND sweeps puzzle off the table, scattering it into a thousand piece ANGLE ON JEFFREY, dancing away while the PATIENT who just completed the puzzle stares, very upset. Other PATIENTS are getting agitated, too, as JEFFREY avoi lunge by BILLINGS and dances off, using PATIENTS as a shi

head_text.subj: I'M GETTING DIZZY. MAKE HIM STOP
FOR ALL GOOD MEN TO SEIZE THE MOMENT

text: ANGLE ON COLE, realizing through the haze of drugs that J is sending a message to him.  COLE looks at the ward door COLE'S POV:  the WARD DOOR opens and two husky ORDERLIES One locks the door with a key, one of many on a key ring to his belt, as the other ORDERLY rushes to join the purs
(missing a tackle)

God damn you, Jeffrey, quit playing the fool. ANGLE ON COLE, hesitating.  He locks at the door...blurri and out of focus.  He looks down at the key in his hand. ANGLE ON JEFFREY, being grabbed by the ORDERLIES.  JEFFRE resists wildly as they struggle to overpower him.

ANGLE ON COLE, moving to the door.  He reaches it and tri insert the key in the lock. ANGLE ON LOCK, as the key keeps missing the hole. ANGLE ON COLE, glancing nervously over his shoulder. COLE'S POV:  ORDERLIES swarm over JEFFREY, don't notice C ANGLE ON COLE, managing to insert the key.  It won't turn A PATIENT, close at hand, startles COLE, speaking into hi
Place to go would be...Florida.  The keys are lovely this tine of year. COLE, unnerved, desperate tries the key again.  It turns.
Be careful.  J. Edgar Hoover isn't really dead. COLE pauses, stares, not understanding.  Then, he opens t

Stepping through the door, COLE finds himself in an ante- facing several elevators. A uniformed SECURITY MAN sitting at a near-by desk doesn' lock up from the magazine he's reading. Barely daring to breathe, COLE steps toward the elevators back is to the SECURITY MAN.  But he doesn't know how to this elevator.  What should he do? SECURITY MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)

Two's not working today.  Use one. COLE freezes, sneaks a glance over his shoulder. COLE'S POV:  the SECURITY MAN continues his reading.  He' guy with reading glasses perched on his nose.  He looks e like the MENACING GUARD IN THE FUTURE...SCARFACE! ANGLE ON COLE, stunned! Just then, an elevator door slides open.  The elevator's COLE steps into it.

The door closes, isolating COLE in the elevator. COLE finds the down button, is about to push it when the springs to life.  The numbers on the indicator over the d start to rise.  7...8...9. Then, the elevator stops and the door opens. Two DOCTORS and an AIDE stand in front of the door, waiti COLE hesitates. They look at him.  They seem to expect him to exit. Avoiding eye contact, COLE exits the elevator. As they enter the elevator, the DOCTORS look back at COLE
RAILLY has just arrived for work.  She's slipping on her doctor's coat when... DR. CASEY, one of the other residents, sticks his head in door waving a crayoned message on a page torn from a maga
This was in my box, but I have a slight suspicion it wasn't meant for me. CASEY enters the room, reading the scrawled words dramati
"You are the most beautiful woman I have ever seen.  You live in a beautiful world.  But you don't know it.  You have freedom, sunshine, air you can breathe."
(smiling)
Cole.  James Cole -- right? She reaches for the note but CASEY moves it out of her gr
"I would do anything to stay here, but I must leave.  Please, help me."
Poor man... CASEY is handing her the note when another resident, DR. sticks his head in the door.  He's upset.
Hey, Kathryn, James Cole is one of yours, right? RAILLY and CASEY stare at him.
He got out.  Took off.  Last seen, he was up on nine.
A PATIENT is being swallowed by a large tube, a CAT SCANN while a DOCTOR in a white coat speaks reassuringly.

Just relax -- don't fight it.  We have to know exactly what's there so we can... The DOCTOR stops, astonished, as the door bursts open. It's COLE!  He stares at the PATIENT and the Cat Scanner. The PATIENT lifts his head up and stares at COLE.
Eh, excuse me.  Can I help you? COLE turns and rushes back out the door.

COLE steps into the corridor, turns to his right, freezes A POSSE of SECURITY GUARDS is headed in his direction. COLE turns to his left. Four ORDERLIES are coming that way. COLE'S trapped.  A beat.  He attacks the nearest man.  BI
RAILLY prepares a hypo, turns to COLE who is strapped tig a gurney with BILLINGS and an RN standing on either side, for more trouble.  One of BILLINGS' eyes is starting to s
It's just a shot to calm you.
No more drugs.  Please...
I have to do this, James.  You're very confused. RAILLY pushes the needle into COLE'S skin.
DR. FLETCHER faces RAILLY across the conference table.  D CASEY, DR. GOODINS, DR. MARILOU MARTIN are also there.
Don't be defensive, Kathryn, this isn't an inquisition.
I didn't think I was being defensive. I was just...
He should have been in restraints.  It was bad judgment on your part, plain and simple.  why not just cop to it?
Okay, it was bad judgment.  But I have the strangest feeling about him -- I've seen him somewhere and...
(impatient, not interested)
Two policemen were already in the hospital and now we have an orderly with a broken arm and a Security Officer with a fractured skull.
I said it was bad judgment!  What else do you want me to say?
You see what I mean?  You're being defensive. (to Dr. Casey)
Isn't she being defensive, Bob? But just then, BILLINGS sticks his head in the door.
Uh, Dr. Fletcher -- we got another... situation.
DR. FLETCHER looks into an empty padded cell as RAILLY, M GOODIN, BILLINGS, PALMER and the NURSE crowd behind him.
He was in full restraints?  And the door was locked?
Yes, sir.  Did it myself.
And he was fully sedated?
He was fully sedated!

Then are you trying to tell me that a fully sedated, fully restrained patient somehow slipped out that vent, replaced the grill behind him and that he's wriggling through the ventilation system right now? DR. FLETCHER indicates an impossibly tiny vent high in th
Seen through the glass windows, a 747 takes off, climbing the sky as the airport P.A. System drones...
Flight 784 to San Francisco now boarding at Gate 38... YOUNG COLE, watching the 747, whirls at the SOUND of a CO MR. PONYTAIL bumps him. The BLONDE MAN sprints past.  The WOMAN'S VOICE calls out

TRAVELERS dive for cover briefly revealing the mysterious running after the BLONDE MAN!  But this time, YOUNG COLE just a glimpse of her face.  She looks a little like RAIL for the dark hair, the make-up. and the flashy earrings. calls out, her VOICE blending weirdly with the P.A. SYSTE
The Freedom For Animals Headquarters now boarding on Second Avenue.  The Army of the Twelve Monkeys... ENGINEER'S VOICE (o.s.)
Cole, you moron -- wake up!
As COLE blinks awake, the digitized monotone of the P.A. continues to drone in an unearthly VOICE...
-- they're the ones who are going to do it... COLE'S eyes seek the source of the sound and find it on t in front of the panel of disapproving SCIENTISTS facing h a beat-up old tape recorder.
I can't do anything more.  The Police are after me. The tape ends, runs off the reel, flap...flap...flap...
Well?
Uh, what?
He's drugged out of his mind!  He's completely zoned out.
Cole, did you or did you not record that message?
Uh, that message...me?
It's a digital reconstruction of a message, Cole, from a weak signal on our contact number.  Did you make that call?
(angrily)
I couldn't call!  You sent me to the wrong year!  It was 1989.
The SCIENTISTS react, exchanging looks, whispers.  Then,
You're certain of that?
(before Cole can answer)
What did you do with your time, Cole? Did you waste it on drugs?  Women?
They forced me to take drugs.
Forced you!  Why would someone force you to take drugs?

I got into trouble.  I got arrested. But I still got you a specimen -- a spider -- but I didn't have anyplace to put it, so I ate it.  It was the wrong year anyway, so I guess it doesn't matter. The SCIENTISTS stare incredulously, then turn, exchange k looks, huddle, start whispering to one another. Struggling to stay awake COLE sees, blurrily, the MICROBI staring at COLE intently.  For one moment, the face belon
COLE blinks hard...and the MICROBIOLOGIST has his own fac COLE'S head slumps forward now...and everything goes dark GEOLOGIST'S VOICE (o.s.)
Cole!
COLE comes awake with a start.  The room is dark now, exc a slide is being projected on a torn screen.  It's a pict stenciled graffiti...the logo of The Army of the 12 Monke
What about it, Cole?
Did you see it?
Uh, no, sir.  I... Another slide CLICKS into place.  Youthful PROTESTERS, th placards featuring slogans and images of Animal Atrocitie confront POLICE in riot gear.

What about these people?  Did you see any of these people? Zooming in, panning, the SCIENTISTS emphasize the FACES o PROTESTERS.  The FACES are unfamiliar to COLE (though WE recognize some of them later on). COLE (o.s.)
Uh, no, sir, I...wait! The image pans back to a much enlarged blurry FACE among PROTESTERS.  In spite of the poor image, the expression o is clear, and it seems to resemble a somewhat older JEFFR
Him?  You saw that man?
Uh, I think so.  In the mental hospital.
(switching on the light)
You were in a mental institution?! The SCIENTISTS MUTTER disapprovingly among themselves.
You were sent to make very important observations!
You could have made a real contribution.
Helped to reclaim the planet...
As well as reducing your sentence.
The question is, Cole -- "Do you want another chance?" COLE stares at them, trying to figure out what they mean.
The BRUNETTE runs up the concourse, her back to YOUNG COL frightened PASSENGERS duck for cover, SHOUTING! RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Hey!  Who's that?
COLE opens his eyes.  Where is he?  Silence as he examine tiny cell.  Bare cement walls.  High ceiling.  Same color size as the isolation room at the county hospital. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Hey, Bob...what's your name? COLE looks around frantically.  Up, down.  Where is the V coming from?  Maybe from that tiny vent high in the wall.
Where are you? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
You can talk!  Wah'dja do, Bobby boy? Volunteer?
My name's not "Bob". RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Not a prob, Bob.  Where'd they send you?
Where are you? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Another cell. ...  Maybe.
What do you mean, "maybe"?  What's that supposed to mean? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

Maybe.  Means "maybe" I'm in the next cell, another "volunteer" like you -- or "maybe" I'm in the Central Office spying on you for all those science bozos.  Or, hey, "maybe" I'm not even here.  "Maybe" I'm just in your head.  No way to confirm anything. Ha Ha.  Where'd they send you? COLE doesn't answer. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Not talking, huh, Bob?  That's okay I can handle that.
RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
89!  How was it?  Good drugs?  Lotsa pussy?  Hey, Bob, you do the job?  D'ju find out the "big info"?...Army of the Twelve Monkeys...where the virus was prior to mutation?
It was supposed to be 1995. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)
Science isn't an exact science with these clowns.  You're lucky you didn't end up in ancient Egypt!
COLE is strapped on a gurney.  SCIENTISTS hover near-by, whispering.  The walls of the gloomy chamber are damp, sw
No mistakes this time, Cole.
Stay alert.  Keep your eyes open.
Good thinking about that spider, Cole. Try and do something like that again.

Just relax now -- don't fight it.  We have to know exactly what's there so we can fix it. The gurney is being wheeled into a crudely welded steel t reminiscent of the cat scanner in County Hospital. COLE'S POV:  a last glimpse of anxious FACES, then the ch door is CLANGED shut.

head_text.subj: EVERYTHING IS BLACK. A HUM BUILDS. THE BLACKNESS VIBRAT
HUM REACHES A DEAFENING LEVEL, THEN DIMUENDOS. WE BEGIN
BURSTS OF MACHINE GUN FIRE, VOICES SHOUTING IN FRENCH, A

text: DRIZZLING RAIN.  And SCREAMS.  COLE'S in a deep trench, n eyes wide with terror. What's going on? Where is he?  SOL in gas masks push urgently past him rushing toward their COMRADES who've been ripped apart by the shell that just fifteen yards away.  Muffled VOICES shout through gas mas in FRENCH.  COLE doesn't know it, but this is World War I Suddenly, a SERGEANT confronts him, shouting in French.
(FRENCH, subtitled)
Where's your mask?!  And your clothes... and your weapon, you idiot?!

What?  What?? COLE looks around desperately.  A horribly WOUNDED MAN is stretchered past them in the narrow trench.  Machine guns close at hand.  AAK AAK AAK.  A grenade EXPLODES.  Reacti foreign word, the SERGEANT jams his bayonet into COLE'S r
(FRENCH, subtitled)
Captain!  A Kraut!  We got a Kraut!
I don't understand.  Where am I? The CAPTAIN hurries over, snapping at COLE in German.
(GERMAN, subtitled)
How'd you get here, soldier?  What's your rank?  Where are your clothes?
I...don't understand.
(frowning, GERMAN, subtitled)
German!  Speak German!  What are you doing here? VOICE (o.s.) (pleading in English)

I gotta find 'em.  I gotta find 'em. Please, you gotta help me! COLE turns, sees... It's his friend, JOSE, the Puerto Rican kid from the next the "underground" time.  He's being carried past COLE now stretcher, blood all over his torso, horribly wounded.

Cole!  Oh, God, Cole, where are we? JOSE reaches out to COLE just as a PHOTOGRAPHER takes a F PICTURE of the kid being carried off on the stretcher.  S SHOTS RING OUT.  COLE goes down.  Hit in the leg! SOLDIERS in gas masks rush past him like giant insects. Looking to his left, COLE sees the CAPTAIN lying beside h from a chest wound, his gas mask half off. COLE is reaching for the mask when... A SHELL HITS CLOSE BY WITH AN ENORMOUS EXPLOSION.

Stunningly quiet.  We are on a placid campus looking at t dignified architecture of Breitrose Hall.  MOVING IN we F a large poster advertising "The Alexander Lectures, Sprin WE SKIM the listings (Jon Else on The Nuclear Agony, Dr. Miksztal on Biological Ethics, etc.) until we SETTLE ON..
MADNESS AND APOCALYPTIC VISIONS

A large screen dominates the auditorium stage.  On the sc a slide of an engraving from the Middle Ages showing a MA apparent agony, his mouth shaped to a scream, as he is re by PEASANTS.  The projector ZOOMS slowly in on the agoniz of this MADMAN as we HEAR RAILLY'S VOICE lecturing. RAILLY'S VOICE (o.s.)

According to the accounts of local officials at that time, this gentleman, judged to be about forty years of age, appeared suddenly in the village of Wyle near Stonehenge in the West of England in April of 1162.  Using unfamiliar words and speaking in a strange accent, the man made dire prognostications about a pestilence which he predicted would wipe out humanity in approximately 8OO years.  Deranged and hysterical, the man raped a young woman of the village, was taken into custody, but then mysteriously escaped and was not heard of again. WE DISCOVER RAILLY, six years older now, standing at a le in a pool of light.  She's dwarfed by the giant screen wh engraving is replaced by a series of slides of woodcuts s scenes of pestilence in the Middle Ages as she lectures t audience of mostly SCHOLARLY TYPES. RAILLY (cont.)

In 1841, Mackay wrote, "During seasons of great pestilence, men have often believed the prophecies of crazed fanatics, that the end of the world was come."  Obviously, this plague/doomsday scenario is considerably more compelling when reality supports it in some form, whether it's the Bubonic Plague, smallpox, or AIDS.  In addition to these "natural" contagions, there are now technological horrors as well:  besides radiation, consider our lurking fear of germ warfare and its close approximation, chemical warfare, which first reared its ugly head in the deadly mustard gas attacks during the First World War. ON THE SCREEN, a SERIES of SLIDES show images of WORLD WA SOLDIERS in gas masks, in death throes, etc.. RAILLY'S VOICE (cont. o.s.)

During such an attack in the French trenches in October, 1917, we have an account of this soldier... ON THE SCREEN, a slide of an old deteriorated photograph JOSE, the Puerto Rican kid, strapped to a stretcher, bein by SOLDIERS through the trenches during an attack.  JOSE to be ranting madly as the projector ZOOMS CLOSER on his the image approximates Munch's famous painting. RAILLY'S VOICE (cant. o.s.)

-- who, during an assault, was wounded by shrapnel and hospitalized behind the lines where Doctors discovered he had lost all comprehension of French but spoke English fluently, albeit in a regional dialect they didn't recognize. The man, although physically unaffected by the gas, was hysterical.  He claimed he had come from the future, that he was looking for a pure germ that would ultimately wipe mankind off the face of the earth in the year... 1995! The AUDIENCE gives a nervous CHUCKLE. ON THE SCREEN, a different old photograph of JOSE.  This he's in a military hospital, gaunt, haunted, very ill. RAILLY'S VOICE (cont. o.s.)

Although seriously injured, the young soldier disappeared from the hospital before more data could be gathered.  No doubt, he was trying to carry on his mission to warn others, substituting for the agony of war...a self-inflicted agony we call the "Cassandra Complex". As RAILLY continues, we SCAN the AUDIENCE and DISCOVER MA RAILLY'S friend, and MARILOU'S HUSBAND, WAYNE CHANG, both attentively.  Further away, another MAN listens intently. shoulder-length carrot-colored hair.  His name is DR. PET RAILLY (cont.)

Cassandra, in Greek legend you will recall, was condemned to know the future but to be disbelieved when she foretold it.  Hence, the agony of foreknowledge combined with impotence to do anything about it.

A stack of new books.  THE DOOMSDAY SYNDROME, Apocalyptic Visions of the Mentally Ill by Dr. Kathryn Railly Surrounded by enthusiastic members of the audience, RAILL seated at the table signing books but DR. PETERS has her

I think, Dr. Railly, you have given your alarmists a bad name.  Surely there is very real and very convincing data that the planet cannot survive the excesses of the human race:  proliferation of atomic devices, uncontrolled breeding habits, the rape of the environment, the pollution of land, sea, and air.  In this context, isn't it obvious that "Chicken Little" represents the sane vision and that Homo Sapiens' motto, "Let's go shopping!" is the cry of the true lunatic? DR. PETERS smiles self-importantly at RAILLY as an elderl disheveled PROFESSOR elbows in front of him.

Doctor Railly -- please!  I wonder if you're aware of my own studies which indicate that certain cycles of the moon actually impact on the incidence of apocalyptic predictions as observed in urban emergency rooms and... As the PROFESSOR babbles, MARILOU MARTIN and her husband, CHANG, appear and whisper...
You were great.
You're leaving?
The reservation's at nine thirty -- it's getting late.
Doctor Railly -- please -- this is very important!
(checking the professor)
You sure you're gonna be all right?
(smiles, checks her watch)
I'll be there in twenty minutes.
Dr. Railly, I simply cannot understand your exclusion of the moon in relation to apocalyptic dementia...

A full moon. COLLEAGUES in a VOLVO pull out of the parking lot, callin "Congratulations" to RAILLY. She waves back as she hurries to her black ACURA, one of cars left in the lot. The outside lights of Breitrose Hall go off. RAILLY seems to be alone in the lot as she fishes keys fr purse, unlocks her car door, starts to open it when... Suddenly, she's grabbed from behind in a choke-hold by a shadowy MAN looming out of the darkness behind her.
Get in! Unable to scream, she writhes and kicks as he forces her front seat.
I've got a gun. RAILLY freezes, terrified, as he opens the rear door and scrambles in behind her.
Fighting to suppress the quaver in her voice, RAILLY says
You can have my purse.  I have a lot of cash and credit... MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)
Start the car. Glancing in the rear view mirror, RAILLY sees penetrating peering out of the shadows, no other features. Half-turning in the seat, she holds out the keys to him.
Here!  You can have the keys.  You can... He grabs her hair and yanks her head back hard, speaking into her ear, his face last in shadow.
The engine STARTS, the Acura backs up, then heads for the
Steering fearfully, RAILLY hears him speak more calmly no MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)

I don't want to hurt you.  But I will. I've hurt people before when...when I had no choice.  Turn left. As she makes the turn, RAILLY glances in the rear view mi sees him unfolding a tattered map.  His face is lost in d but she glimpses ragged, torn clothing as he tries to rea map by the intermittent glow of passing street lights.
Where... where are we going'
I need you to drive me to Philadelphia.
(startled, horrified)
But that's... that's more than 200 miles!

That's why I can't walk there.  Turn here... I think... RAILLY obeys.  She glances in the mirror again, hesitates boldly switches on the dome light, holding her breath fea for his reaction. He grunts appreciatively.  Relieved, she looks in the mir again, trying to get a better look at him, but now his fe are concealed by the map.
If you make me go with you, it's kidnapping.  That's a serious crime. If you let me go, you could just take the car and...

I don't know how to drive!  We went underground when I was nine, I told you that.  When you come to the corner, turn right. Startled, RAILLY whirls, looks right at him. He's lowered the map.  It's COLE!  Haggard, unshaven, dir
Cole!  James Cole!  You escaped from a locked room six years ago.
1989.  Six years for you.  There's the sign!  Right here! COLE is indicating a freeway entrance. RAILLY turns the wheel sharply.
The Acura veers up the ramp and onto the freeway.
RAILLY glances in the mirror, sees COLE settling back wea against the seat.  She says carefully...
I can't believe this is a coincidence, Mr. Cole.  Have you been...following me?

You told me you'd help me.  I know this isn't what you meant, but...I was desperate... no money...bum leg... sleeping on the streets. I probably smell bad.  Sorry about that. But then I saw your book in a store window with a notice about your lecture. (sudden pride)
I can read, remember?
Yes, I remember. (a beat, then)
Why do you want to go to Philadelphia?
It's the next step.  I checked out the Baltimore information, it was nothing. It's Philadelphia, that's where they are, the ones who killed everyone. (pointing suddenly, eagerly)
Zs that a radio?  Does it play music? RAILLY turns on the radio and immediately WE HEAR the SOU and the CRIES of gulls, background to an oozing baritone COMMERCIAL/RADIO (o.s.)
This is a personal message to you. COLE sits up, alert, listening intently. COMMERCIAL/RADIO (cont. o.s.)
Are you at the end of your rope?  Are you dying to get away? COLE'S eyes narrow, concentrating on this personal messag COMMERCAIL/RADIO (cont. o.s.}
The Florida Keys are waiting for you. COLE frowns as the SOUND of breaking SURF and crying GULL the car.  It's confusing!  He blurts out...
I've never seen the ocean! Observing his confusion in the mirror, RAILLY assumes her professional tone.
It's an advertisement, Mr. Cole.  You do understand that, don't you?  It's not really a special message to you. COLE frowns.  He did think it was for him, but she's prob
You used to call me "James".
You'd prefer that? ... James...you don't really have a gun, do you.
(cynical laugh)
Everybody's got a gun.  In this city... He breaks off reacting to the RADIO MUSIC!  FATS DOMINO s "BLUEBERRY HILL"!  COLE grins, mouth agape, eyes wide lik

Can you...can you make it louder?  I love hearing twentieth century music! Hearing music and breathing air! As RAILLY cranks up the volume, she watches the mirror incredulously, sees him stick his head out the window int wind, mouth open, "eating" the air hungrily.
"BLUEBERRY HILL" BLARES as the Acura, COLE'S head out the window, zips past a sign at 65 mph. The sign says, "PHILADELPHIA 233 MILES."
RAILLY glances in the mirror at the nut in the rear seat head out the window.  what can she do?  Just then, while trying to figure something out, an ANNOUNCER'S VOICE brea ANNOUNCER/RADIO (o.s.)

This just in from Fresno, California: emergency crews are converging on a cornfield where playmates of nine year old Ricky Neuman say they saw him disappear right before their eyes. COLE pulls his head back inside with a frown, troubled no ANNOUNCER/RADIO (cont. o.s.)

Young Neuman apparently stepped into an abandoned well shaft and is lodged somewhere in the narrow 150 foot pipe, possibly alive, possibly seriously injured.  Playmates claim they heard him cry out faintly but since then there has been no contact with...
"Never cry wolf!"
What?
My father told me that.  "Never cry wolf."  Then people won't believe you if...something really happens.
"If something really happens"...like what, James?
Something bad.  Is that all the music? I don't want to hear this stuff... RAILLY glances at him as she scans stations.
Did something terrible happen to you when you were a child?  Something so bad...?
Ohhhh, that one!  Can we hear that one? It's IVORY JOE HUNTER singing, "SINCE I MET YOU, BABY". IVORY JOE/RADIO (o.s.)
"Since I met you, baby, My whole life has changed... Ecstatic, COLE sticks his head out the window again.
COLE'S POV:  the heavens, glittering with a million stars lover's moon as IVORY JOE croons the achingly romantic ly IVORY JOE/RADIO (cont. o.s.)
"-- cause since I met you, baby. All I need is you..." ANGLE ON COLE, wind in his hair, eyes shining, gulping ai
Two POLICE OFFICERS and an anxious MARILOU MARTIN listen answering machine's message while a hungry CAT cries plai

Dr. Railly -- this is Palmer from Psych Admitting.  There was a guy here this afternoon looking for you.  He seemed very agitated.  We tried to keep him, but he refused 'n I kept thinking, I know this guy.  Then, just a few minutes ago, it came to me.  It's Cole!  James Cole. Remember him?  The paranoid who pulled the Houdini back in '89.  Well, he's back and he's...cuckoo...and he's looking for you.  I thought you oughta know. The machine switches off.  The POLICE OFFICERS exchange a
It's just as I told you -- my husband and I had gone ahead -- she never showed.  That's totally unlike her!
(pulls out his notebook)
Do you happen to know the make of her car?
Um...Acura...'92 Acura. ... Also, that cat's starving!  She would never neglect her cat!
The ACURA is parked outside room 46 of the HIGHWAYS & BYW MOTEL, which has definitely seen better days.
The TV is on.  A commercial is just starting.  A catfood The sound of HEAVY BREATHING. ANGLE ON COLE, sweating, BREATHING HEAVILY, sprawled on o of the double bed, sound asleep.

GUNSHOT!  YOUNG COLE glimpses the BLONDE MAN staggering, The mysterious BRUNETTE races past him toward the BLONDE YOUNG COLE again glimpses the resemblance to RAILLY, in s the dark hair, the make-up, the flashy earrings. Close at hand, YOUNG COLE'S FATHER, his face still out of FATHER'S VOICE (o.s.)
Son, it's important for your cat to have the nourishment necessary for healthy bones and a rich coat.
COLE comes awake with a start.  He stares, disoriented, a CATFOOD COMMERCIAL on the TV. RAILLY'S VOICE (o.s.)

Please untie me.  I'm very uncomfortable. COLE turns to RAILLY, beside him on the bed, frightened a helpless, her jacket arranged to restrain her like a stra COLE'S instinct is to free her at once, but he controls h impulse.  He looks away, gets up, and, wincing, limps to dresser, stepping around empty fast-food cartons.  He pul razor and shaving soap from a paper bag, then goes into t bathroom, leaving the door open, and starts to shave.
You were in my dream just now.  Your hair was different, but I'm sure it was you.
We dream about what's important in our lives. And I seem to have become pretty important in yours.  What was the dream about?
About an airport...before everything happened.  It's the same dream I always have -- the only one.  I'm a little kid in it.
And I was in it?  What did I do?
You were very upset.  You're always very upset in the dream, but I never knew it was you before.
It wasn't me before, James.  It's become me now because of...what's happening.  Please untie me. Finished shaving, COLE re-enters the bedroom, toweling hi
No, I think it was always you.  It's very strange.
You're flushed.  And you were moaning. I think you're running a fever.  What are you doing? COLE is rummaging through RAILLY'S wallet, pulling out mo
I'll be back in a minute. He heads for the door.
No!  Don't leave me here like this! Too late!  He shuts the door behind him, leaving her alon ANGLE ON THE TV SCREEN, where an ANCHORMAN sits at a News

And in Fresno, California...crews continue to attempt to rescue nine year old Ricky Neuman. ANGLE ON RAILLY, twisting and struggling on the bed, tryi get loose, tears welling in her eyes. TV ANCHORMAN (cont. o.s.)
The boy was playing ball with four other children when he literally disappeared off the face of the earth.
COLE puzzles over a junk food vending machine, inserts co
ANGLE ON TV, the picture of RAILLY filling the screen.
My notes.  Observations.  Clues.
Clues?  What kind of clues?
A secret army.  The Army of The Twelve Monkeys.  I've told you about them. They spread the virus.  That's why we have to get to Philadelphia.  I have to find them -- it's my assignment.
What will you do...when you find this...secret army?

I just have to locate the virus in its original form before it mutates.  So scientists can come back and study it and find a cure.  So that those of us who survived can go back to the surface of the earth. RAILLY maintains a professional deadpan, says nothing as a pickup truck with a MOTHER, FATHER, and five KIDS in th COLE stares at the KIDS, a sad look in his eyes.

You won't think I'm crazy next month. People are going to start dying.  At first the papers will say it's some weird fever, some virus.  Then they'll begin to catch on.  They'll get it. RADIO NEWSCASTER (o.s.)
We interrupt this program with a special bulletin... RAILLY and COLE both react to the radio, suddenly alert. RADIO NEWSCASTER (o.s.)
This report just in from Fresno, California.  Naval sonar specialists who were flown to the site...
I thought it was about us.  I thought maybe they'd found us and arrested me or something. RAILLY stares at COLE.
Just a joke. RADIO NEWSCASTER (o.s.)

-- an hour ago have been unable to determine the location of the boy in the 150 foot shaft...but a TV sound man who lowered an ultra-sensitive microphone into the narrow tube claims he heard breathing sounds coming from approximately seventy feet down... COLE reaches over and changes stations.  MUSIC again.
Does that disturb you, James?  Thinking about that little boy in the well?
When I was a kid I identified with that kid, down there alone in that pipe...a hundred feet down -- doesn't know if they're going to save him.
What do you mean -- when you were a kid?
Nevermind.  It's not real -- it's a hoax.  A prank.  He's hiding in a barn. Hey, turn left here.  Left! COLE quickly checks the map as RAILLY stares, then turns
An elderly EVANGELIST with long stringy hair, wearing a t bathrobe, stands on a Skid Row corner WAVING a worn Bible rants at disinterested DERELICTS, WINOS, and BAG LADIES.

"And the wild beasts of the islands shall cry in their desolate houses and dragons in their pleasant palaces:  and her time is near to come, and her days shall not be prolonged." ANGLE ON RAILLY'S ACURA, crawling down the street, RAILLY COLE, beside her, staring out the window.
COLE is scrutinizing the crumbling walls, boarded-up stor fronts, tattered posters, decaying signs, miserable "RESI

Where I come from we think of this as Eden. If we could just see the sun, eat sun-grown food.  Eden!  Look at them!  They donut know what they have.  They don't see the sky.  They don't feel the air! COLE'S POV:  a BMW speeds toward them, passes, its radio COLE (o.s.)
And the ones who aren't hungry are so smug they haven't a clue.  WAIT!  STOP!

On foot now, COLE pulls an astonished RAILLY to a wall co graffiti, a hopeless tangle of symbols, words, and crude Clueless, RAILLY stares at the wall, then at COLE. COLE touches a bit of red-stenciled graffiti hidden under insignias.  We can just see TWELVE MONKEYS holding hands
The Twelve Monkeys!!!  They're here. (looks around)

Somewhere.  Come on! He pulls her along the sidewalk.  No question, he's insan At the next alley entrance, COLE stops abruptly.  Then, s keeping a firm grip on RAILLY'S arm, he starts ripping do tacked-up posters announcing a Rap concert. RAILLY stares at him, then turns and is looking all aroun suddenly, COLE pulls her up tight and threatens...
Look, I'm warning you.  You do anything, I'm going to go crazy -- hurt people!

I'm not going to "do" anything, I promise.  But you need help, James. None of this is what you think it is. ANGLE ON COLE, not listening, staring triumphantly!  He's another partially obscured stencil of THE TWELVE MONKEYS! But just then, a raspy VOICE startles COLE. RASPY VOICE (o.s)
You can't hide from them, Bob. COLE whirls, sees a derelict, LOUIE, leering at him, spea voice eerily like the RASPY VOICE from the next cell in t
No, sir, Old Bob -- don't even try. (conspiratorially)
They hear everything.  They got that tracking device on you.  They can find you anywhere.  Anytime.  Ha Ha! RAILLY looks from LOUIS to COLE, sees COLE'S stunned reac
(touches his back jaw)
In the tooth, Bob!  Right? (sudden triumphant grin)
But I fooled 'em, old buddy! He opens his mouth wide.  NO TEETH' COLE grabs RAILLY and pulls her into the alley and down i
They're keeping an eye on me.
Who's keeping an eye on you?

The man...with the voice.  I recognized him.  He's from the present.  He... COLE breaks off, freezes as he sees... there on a brick wall is a stencil of the DANCING MONKEYS And further on, another red stencil!

CRACKHEADS huddle against a building, sucking their pipes oblivious to COLE pulling RAILLY past. COLE scans the walls for messages in the confusion of gra RAILLY is considering her surroundings dubiously when, su COLE pulls her toward the mouth of a dark and forbidding
James, no -- we shouldn't be here! COLE ignores her, yanking her after him into the alley.

Two TOM CATS face off, arching their backs and HISSING me COLE avoids them as he pulls RAILLY into the gloom. ANGLE ON RAILLY, seeing something alarming twenty yards a RAILLY'S POV:  TWO THUGS, standing over a MAN, kicking hi RAILLY tries to stop, but COLE, intent on the wall messag doesn't notice the THUGS. The TWO THUGS turn and spot COLE and RAILLY moving toward These creeps have mean eyes, predator faces. RAILLY digs her heels in, forcing COLE to stop.
James!  We have to go back.  Those men... Too late.  While COLE turns and stares at her, uncomprehe the TWO THUGS are approaching.

Hey, buddy. Startled, COLE turns to face them. The SECOND THUG lunges for RAILLY'S purse, yanks it from COLE reaches to grab it back, but...WHACK!  The FIRST THU COLE hard across the face with something metallic. Bloody-faced, dazed, COLE doesn't even have a chance to c head as the FIRST THUG shoves the hard object against COL cheek.  It's a cheap thirty-eight pistol. RAILLY turns to run, gets two steps before the SECOND THU her roughly to the ground.
Stick around, bitch. Looming over her, the SECOND THUG starts to unzip his fly RAILLY looks over to COLE, SEES... COLE dropping to his knees, groveling at the FIRST THUG'S

Please!  Please don't hurt me! The FIRST THUG steps close, kicks COLE contemptuously, co foot for a second kick when... COLE uncoils, lunging, rising, his strong arms around the man's calves, lifting him mightily, high off the ground. The gun FIRES wildly as COLE staggers forward with the FI in his arms and smashes the man into the brick wail behin The FIRST THUG goes down in a heap, dropping the pistol. Zipping his fly hastily, the SECOND THUG turns to deal wi but COLE attacks him....rocking him again and again with blows that come one after another with lightning speed. THUG staggers back, bloody and dazed as RAILLY watches, a Turning back to the FIRST THUG, COLE sees the MAN reachin the dropped pistol. COLE kicks him viciously in the jaw.  The FIRST THUG'S he back.  SNAP!  He collapses against the brick wall. COLE turns back to see the SECOND THUG retreating down th as fast as he can stagger. RAILLY stares up at COLE.  He looks very dangerous.  He g in her direction as he pockets the pistol.
Are you hurt?
Uh, no.  Yes.  I mean, just some scrapes... As RAILLY gets to her feet, she sees COLE bend over the motionless THUG and quickly go through his pockets.
Is he...alive? COLE ignores the question as he pockets the man's wallet handful of bullets, then turns and snaps at RAILLY.
Come an.  We're running out of time. You can't help him. As COLE yanks her roughly away, she looks back, sees the THUG'S sightless eyes, wide open...staring blankly.
Oh, Jesus, James!  You killed him!
I did him a favor.  Now come on. COLE, pulling her again, sees more "12 MONKEYS" on the wa
You didn't have a gun before, did you?
I've got one now.
The EVANGELIST, spotting COLE and RAILLY hurrying past hi points urgently at COLE.
You!  You!  You're one of us, aren't you? But COLE has stopped and is staring at... A STOREFRONT OFFICE...its windows covered with posters. over the office says, FREEDOM FOR ANIMALS ASSOCIATION.

Earnest young activists, FALE, deathly pale, BEN, long ha and TEDDY, muscular, are gathered around a counter collat leaflets that demand an END TO SPECIEISM.  Behind them, a poster proclaims, "ANIMALS HAVE SOULS, TOO".  Just then, a tremendous CLAP OF THUNDER as the ACTIVISTS look up and COLE and RAILLY enter. COLE looks startled.  It sounds like torrential RAIN POUR here.  Maintaining a tight grip on RAILLY'S wrist, he loo around frantically for an explanation for the tropical do Bookshelves line two walls.  The front window is blanked posters of Animal Rights demonstrations, newspaper clippi photos of animal atrocities.  The fourth wall features th counter where the three ACTIVISTS face COLE as a JUNGLE B SCREAMS in the DOWNPOUR.
Uh, can we help you? COLE looks confused as the RAIN abates and an ELEPHANT tr an urgent warning.
Excuse me.  You looking for something in particular?
It's all right, James -- it's just a tape. COLE'S eyes follow her look.  It's a tape recorder undern sign advertising, "THE TRUE MUSIC OF THE WORLD".

I, uh, I'm looking for the, ah, the Army of the Twelve Monkeys. FALE glances at BEN and TEDDY.  "We have a problem!" the MONKEYS start CHATTERING on the tape as TEDDY comes aroun counter, bigger than COLE, physically imposing, menacing.
We don't know anything about any "Army of the Twelve Monkeys", so why don't you and your friend disappear, okay? COLE backs away, a firm grip on RAILLY, as a LION ROARS.
I just need some information...
Didn't you hear me?  We're not... TEDDY breaks off mid-sentence...freezes. COLE is pointing a pistol at them.  A TIGER SNARLS.
James, no -- don't hurt them. (to the activists)
Please, I'm a psychiatrist -- just do whatever he tells you to do.  He's... upset -- disturbed.  Please -- he's dangerous -- just cooperate. MONKEYS CHATTER wildly as TEDDY backs up.
What do you want -- money?  We only have a few bucks. COLE is suddenly very much in charge and self-confident a BABOON HOWLS with laughter.
I told you what I want. (snaps at Railly)
Lock the door!
James, why don't we...?
Lock it now! RAILLY hurries to the door to lock it as BEN says to FALE
I told you that fuckhead Mason would get us into something like this.
Shut up!
Mason???
Jeffrey Mason?
Yeah, tucking, crazy Jeffrey Mason.
The three ACTIVISTS are tied tightly together in the midd the floor in this dimly-lit, windowless basement.  They'r frightened, eager to cooperate.
Then, Jeffrey becomes like this...big star -- the media latch on to him because he's picketing his own father, a "famous Nobel Prize winning virologist". You musta seen all that on TV.
No, I don't watch TV. COLE, the gun next to him, rummages through boxes of pape RAILLY watches helplessly.  Suddenly, COLE finds somethin thinks he's seen before.  He holds it up.
Is this him -- Dr. Mason? It's a photograph of DR. MALCOLM MASON, being escorted by phalanx of riot cops through a mob of raging activists.
That's him.
(very frightened)
What are you going to do with us?
(stares at the photo, then)
Tell me more about Jeffrey.
(a helpless shrug to his cohorts)

Jeffrey started getting bored with the shit we do...picketing, leafleting, letter-writing stuff.  He said we were, "ineffectual liberal jerkoffs".  He wanted to do guerrilla "actions" to "educate" the public. COLE holds up a clipping showing horrified SENATORS stand their desks as RATTLESNAKES slither along the Senate Floo
Yeah, that's when he let a hundred snakes loose in the Senate.
But we weren't into that kind of stuff. It's counter productive, we told him.
So he and eleven others split off and became this underground..."army"
The Army of The Twelve Monkeys.
They started planning a "Human Hunt".
They bought stun guns and nets and bear traps.  They were gonna go to Wall Street and trap lawyers and bankers...
But they didn't do it.  They didn't do any of it.
Yeah, just like always, Mr. Big Shot sold his friends out!
What's that mean?

He goes on TV, gives a news conference, tells the whole world he just realized his daddy's experiments are vital for humanity and that the use of animals is absolutely necessary and that he, Jeffrey Mason, from now on, is going to personally supervise the labs to make sure all the little animals aren't going to suffer.
(holding up a rolodex)
What's this?
In the crawling traffic, WE FIND a battered FORD covered bumper stickers and painted slogans.  "I BRAKE FOR ANIMAL

head_text.subj: "FREE THE ANIMALS"..."WOULD YOU LET A MINK WEAR YOUR SKIN

text: RAILLY (v.o.)
You can't just barge in on a famous scientist.  They'll have security guards, gates, alarm systems.  It's insane, James.

A ROLODEX CARD with an address on "Outerbridge Road" for Mason c/o Dr. Malcolm Mason" rests on a map spread across lap.  COLE is in the passenger seat, RAILLY'S at the whee maneuvering in heavy traffic.
If those young men don't get loose, they could die in that basement. COLE glances out the window, indicates the PEOPLE in pass cars...COMMUTERS, FAMILIES, TRUCKERS.
All I see are dead people.  Everywhere. What's three more?
(a beat, carefully, a new tack)
You know Dr. Mason's son, Jeffrey Mason, don't you, James?  You met him in the County Hospital six years ago. COLE is studying the map again.
The guy was a total fruitcake.
And he told you then his father was a famous virologist. COLE is absorbed in the map, his finger tracing "Outerbri
No -- he said his father was "God"!

The RADIO BLARES a country song as the Ford zips along an highway.  COLE has his head out the window, sucking air, the music, but his bliss is feverish now -- he's not well the SONG ends, he pulls his head inside.  An ANNOUNCER'S intones over the RADIO... RADIO ANNOUNCER (o.s.)

This just in:  police are widening their search for Dr. Kathryn Railly, prominent psychiatrist and author. Authorities confirm that Dr. Railly has been abducted by escaped mental patient, James Cole. The two are believed to be traveling in Railly's 1992 black Acura, license plate H-E-A-D-D-R. RAILLY glances at him, sees he's in pain.  She feels so b him.  She wants to help him.  She says, tenderly...
This can't go on, James.  You're not well.  You're burning with fever. COLE, refusing to succumb, instead, leans over to check t
We need gas.
I thought you didn't know how to drive.
I said I was too young to drive.  I didn't say I was stupid.
What's the matter with your leg?
I got shot.  Look -- there's a gas station up ahead.
Shot!  Who shot you?
It was some kind of...war.  Never mind, you wouldn't believe me.  Turn off here.
The GAS STATION ATTENDANT checks the oil while COLE and R remain in the car.  She's pulling a gas card from her wal
You were going to run out off gas on purpose, weren't you?
No.  I want you to turn yourself in, James -- It'll go much better for you if you do -- but I'm not going to trick you.
(sees the credit card)

That has your name on it.  Give him cash. RAILLY puts the card back into her wallet and pulls out c the GAS STATION ATTENDANT slams the hood down. RAILLY starts opening the door.  Alarmed, COLE tries to s
Where are you going? She looks him in the eye, then indicates the tiny Conveni Store appended to the Gas Station.

You can come with me.  I have to get some things.  Scissors, bandages, some alcohol or whiskey. ... I have to look at your leg, James.  I'm a doctor. COLE looks helpless, hesitant.  She's in charge...for the
The sun dazzles through the canopy of leaves.  We HEAR th RADIO but not the engine. RADIO ANNOUNCER (v.o.)

Meanwhile in Fresno, where mining engineers continue their desperate attempt to sink a shaft parallel to the ant in which nine year old...
